results.title: Aboriginal legends. No. 3
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description: Three Aboriginal legends gathered from tribal elders by student teachers from Kormilda College, Darwin are retold with accompanying illustrations by the students. The titles include: “Why the Emu cannot fly” - storyteller and artist, Nugget Jabangadi James; “Inganarr, the giant Serpent” - story by Bunug, artist Nathanael Maralngura; “The Bat and the Rainbow” - story by Anastasia Kelantumana, artist Suzanne Chalmers. These stories and pictures can be found in the book entitled “Djugurba”. Narrated by Juliana Allan, Wynne Nelson and Peter Gwynne.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia

results.title: Royal tour of Victoria
results.brief_description:
Begins with the Queen landing at Tullamarine Airport and parading through the city in a car. Massive crowds greet her, the city is decorated in red,white and blue in her honour. This is followed by scenes at night with similar, illuminated decorations.

The next day she opens Parliament in the morning, where she gives a speech, before going to the MCG to meet with thousands of ex-servicemen.

On return from Mt. Gambier she visits the Flemington Race Course and Kooyong Tennis Club. A horse race is named in her honour and she congratulates the winning jockey.

At the Shrine of Rememberance, the queen makes a speech and opens the new forecourt.

Meanwhile, the Duke of Wellington inspects a naval base and views a parade.

A garden party is held in honour of the Queen at Government House.

The Queen and Phillip then briefly visit rural Victorian towns on a train.

Phillip is then shown being greeted by ‘wacky’ students at Melbourne University and visiting a science laboratory.

At the MCG, thousands of school students perform dance and gymnastic routines for the Queen.

After travelling to more country towns, where she is greeted by their excited populace, she returns to Melbourne for a final parade in the city.

At Mildura, she is presented with dried fruit and then flies away from Victoria on the Royal plane.

Good titles/’The End’.

results.title: Aboriginal legends. No. 1
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description: Three Aboriginal legends gathered from tribal elders by student teachers from Kormilda College, Darwin are retold with accompanying illustrations by the students. The titles include: “The thirsty Sandfrog” - story by Miriam Rose Wilson, artist Ralph Gumudul; “The Witchdoctor and the two giants” - story by Lionel Jabanangga James, artist David Gentian; “Why the Kangaroo hops” - story by Nugget Jabangadi James, artist Neville Jabangadi Poulson. These stories and pictures can be found in the book entitled “Djugurba. Narrated by Juliana Allan, Wynne Nelson and Peter Gwynne.

results.title: Aboriginal legends. No. 2
results.creator_credit: David Corke, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media Australia
results.brief_description: Three Aboriginal legends gathered from Tribal elders by student teachers from Kormilda College, Darwin are retold with accompanying illustrations by the students. The titles include: “The Anteater and the Turtle” - story by Nathanael Maralngura, artist Neville Jabangadi Poulson; “The old Dingo who had six wives” - story by Bill Middikari Jambidjimba, artist Harry Djagamara Nelson; “How the Kangaroo got his tail” - Story by Andrew Leku, artist Ralph Gumudul. These stories and pictures can be found in the book entitled “Djugurba”. Narrated by Juliana Allan, Wynne Nelson and Peter Gwynne.

results.title: Aboriginal canoe trees of the Murray
results.creator_credit: Robert Edwards, Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies and South Australian Museum
results.brief_description: First Nations people of the lower Murray River formerly made large canoes from the bark of Red Gum trees. This film documents the felling of a canoe tree from the sides of the Murray and its transportation to the South Australian Museum for preservation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Edwards, Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies and South Australian Museum

results.title: The Abode of peace
results.creator_credit: Ow Kheng Law, B.H. Hipkins and Malayan Film Unit
results.brief_description: The British Protected Sultanate of Brunei lies on the northern coastline of the island of Borneo, between North Borneo and Sarawak. This film is an account of Brunei’s struggle to preserve the best of an old civilisation while using the new prosperity brought by the discovery of oil in the territory to build roads, schools and hospitals.

results.title: Potash deficiency Hamilton district
results.brief_description: No sound. Long-duration shots of clovers, fields and farmers walking through fields. Ends with footage of a manually-operated farming device that either plants seeds or removes plants.

results.title: Abnormal behavior: a mental hospital (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Neil Reichline, Tom Lazarus and CRM Productions
results.brief_description: A series of doctor-patient interviews acquaint the viewer with the symptomatology of various types of schizophrenic disturbances. In an unusual sequence, a patient with paranoid tendencies is shown undergoing electro-convulsive therapy. The director of the hospital tells of the hospital’s goals in this and other forms of treatment.

results.title: Abel Gance: yesterday and tomorrow = Abel Gance: hier et demain
results.creator_credit: D Harispe, N. Kaplan, Q. Ciarlo, R. Picon-Borel, Nelly Kaplan and Office de Documentation par Film
results.brief_description: Yesterday and Tomorrow is a French/English dubbed documentary which summarizes Abel Gance’s entire career, from his days working initially as an actor in the film industry, up until 1963, the year this program was made. The documentary shows excerpts of his films including shorts like “La Folie du Docteur Tube” (1915). It is narrated through “the words of Gance”, who explains how his career was plagued with tragedy and little recognition.
results.title_for_label: Abel Gance: yesterday and tomorrow = Abel Gance: hier et demain

results.title: The ABC's of film direction
results.brief_description: Demonstrates techniques and devices of film production used to create different effects on the screen. Describes types of camera movement, subject movement and lens choice to produce desired effects. Discusses dissolves, fades and cutouts as methods to show passage of time.
results.description: Demonstrates techniques and devices of film production used to create different effects on the screen. Describes types of camera movement, subject movement and lens choice to produce desired effects. Discusses dissolves, fades and cutouts as methods to show passage of time.
